Award.AwardTitle: RIG: Investigating mechanisms of trophic ricochet in canopy food chains resulting from long-term legacies of historic deer browsing
Award.AbstractNarration:
When large mammalian predators are extirpated or hunting pressure from humans is insufficient, mammalian herbivores like white-tailed deer increase in density, exerting increased pressure on plant communities. Though such effects are well-documented, it remains untested how herbivore-induced changes in vegetation ricochet back up the new food chain in these altered plant communities. Making use of a unique long-term experiment where deer density was manipulated in large enclosures, preliminary data demonstrate that deer density during stand initiation (the first 10 yr following clear cut) causes significant legacy effects in forest canopies, including trees, insects, and birds, lasting at least 30 years. The current project investigates mechanisms by which this legacy operates from scales ranging from stand to individual tree to individual prey item. Preliminary data provide support for mechanisms such as reduced foliage density, reduced prey base per unit foliage, and reduced prey quality at high deer density, all due to stand-scale changes in tree species dominance caused by deer. New investigations in these stands include bird foraging observations and bird exclusion experiments to examine at what scale and by what mechanisms birds respond to changes in forest vegetation caused by historic deer browsing.

Results from this study are relevant to the ca. 30% or more of eastern US counties where deer are over-abundant. Findings will be disseminated directly to state, federal, and tribal land managers via training programs coordinated by the USDA Forest Service Northern Research Station. The project will broaden participation by under-represented minorities in three ways. First, the PI is Native American, a group that is under-represented in STEM disciplines, particularly so in ecology. Second, the PI will provide mentorship via Indiana University of Pennsylvania's McNair program, a research mentorship program for undergraduates from under-represented groups interested in pursuing a PhD. Third, the PI will work with IUP students to establish a SEEDS chapter, a program of the Ecological Society of America that seeks to enhance opportunities for students from under-represented group to pursue careers in ecology.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated how human changes to food chains and other aspects of the environment reverberate through ecosystems to affect members of other food chains, an effect we termed “trophic ricochet”. Initially, the project focused on how management decisions affecting density of white-tailed deer drive changes in forest composition, which shape the suite of insects that eat those plants and the birds that eat those insects. Most of the insect herbivores were caterpillars, of which there are hundreds of species in the region. Identification of so many species that are constantly changing in appearance is a major challenge, so we captured caterpillars and reared them in the lab until they achieved identifiable life stages. Those that died before this were identified using DNA barcoding. Our results indicated that deer density has long-lasting effects several levels up food chain supported by the deer-affected plant community. Deer not only change the composition of plant communities, but also the composition and diversity of insect and bird communities.
In the second half of the project, the study system changed to investigating how human-induced changes in stream water quality affected insect communities and the birds that feed on those insects, either within the stream or after they emerge as adult insects. We employed DNA barcoding of bird nestling fecal samples to determine what insects and other invertebrates these birds that live in the forests near the stream were feeding their young. We determined that water quality, as affected by land use and abandoned mine drainage, changed the composition of stream invertebrate communities. Riparian birds appear to compensate for these changes by shifting their diets to include more terrestrial prey species.
This research supported the thesis and dissertation work of four graduate students and provided research experience for nine undergraduate students, five of whom were from under-represented backgrounds. So far, this NSF award has supported three publications in international peer reviewed journals, with more in preparation.


Last Modified: 09/01/2016
Modified by: Timothy Nuttle

Identification of so many species that are constantly changing in appearance is a major challenge, so we captured caterpillars and reared them in the lab until they achieved identifiable life stages. Our results indicated that deer density has long-lasting effects several levels up food chain supported by the deer-affected plant community. Deer not only change the composition of plant communities, but also the composition and diversity of insect and bird communities. In the second half of the project, the study system changed to investigating how human-induced changes in stream water quality affected insect communities and the birds that feed on those insects, either within the stream or after they emerge as adult insects. We employed DNA barcoding of bird nestling fecal samples to determine what insects and other invertebrates these birds that live in the forests near the stream were feeding their young.
